Definition: Converting a problem from one representation to another that makes it more tractable.
Evidence:
- The solver translates the abstract group theory problem into concrete linear algebra: "H is the set of all linear combinations of these vectors with integer coefficients. $H = \{ a(3,8) + b(4,-1) + c(5,4) | a, b, c \in \mathbb{Z} \}$"
- Similarly for $H_{xy}$: "$H_{xy} = \{ m(0,x) + n(1,y) | m, n \in \mathbb{Z} \} = \{ (n, mx+ny) | m, n \in \mathbb{Z} \}$"
Math Example: Consider the additive group  $\mathbb{Z}^{2}$ . Let  $H$  be the smallest subgroup containing  $(3,8), (4,-1)$  and  $(5,4)$ .
